Assume there exists a polynomial \( f(x) \) with integer coefficients.
Represent \( f(x) \) in a general form, \( f(x) = a_nx^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + ... + a_1x + a_0 \), where \( a_i \) are integers.
Use the given values \( f(7) = 11 \) and \( f(11) = 13 \) to set up two equations based on the general form of \( f(x) \).

Substitute \( x = 7 \) and \( x = 11 \) into the polynomial to create the specific equations \( 11 = a_n(7)^n + a_{n-1}(7)^{n-1} + ... + a_1(7) + a_0 \) and \( 13 = a_n(11)^n + a_{n-1}(11)^{n-1} + ... + a_1(11) + a_0 \).
Analyze the two equations to determine possible values for the coefficients \( a_n, a_{n-1}, ..., a_0 \).
Investigate if it is possible to satisfy both conditions using integer solutions.
Conclude whether such a polynomial can exist based on the findings from the previous steps.

Define the problem: Find if there exists a polynomial f(x) with integer coefficients such that f(7)=11 and f(11)=13.
Consider the difference between f(11) and f(7): Compute f(11) - f(7).
Analyze the expression f(11) - f(7) in the context of polynomials: Determine the form of a polynomial f(x) that could potentially satisfy both f(7) = 11 and f(11) = 13.
Examine divisibility conditions: Check if the result from step 3 is divisible by the difference in x-values (11-7).
Conclusion regarding the existence: Summarize whether such a polynomial exists based on the analysis of the polynomial form and divisibility conditions.
